newsitem.title: TAIWAN: New missiles to enter Taiwan service in 1999.
newsitem.headline: New missiles to enter Taiwan service in 1999.

text.p: Taiwan said on Wednesday that the anti-missile Patriot and anti-aircraft Avenger missiles it had bought from the United States would enter service in 1999, boosting the island's defences against its giant rival China.

"As communist China still seeks to take us, we must prepare for the danger in times of peace," Defence Minister Chiang Chung-ling said in his annual administrative report to the Legislative Yuan, or parliament.
"The anti-air Patriots and Avengers are expected to enter service in 1999," he said.
The United States said in 1993 that Taiwan planned a private purchase from U.S. defence giant Raytheon Co of a "Modified Air Defence System" based on the Gulf War-tested Patriot anti-missile missile.
Washington said in August that Taiwan's request to purchase the Avenger was being processed.
China, which has regarded Taiwan as a renegade province since the Chinese civil war split them in 1949, has angrily protested at the sales, of which the numbers of missiles were not disclosed.
Despite switching diplomatic recognition to Beijing from Taipei in 1979, Washington reserves the right to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons.
China threatens to recover Taiwan by force if it seeks independence. Taipei says it wants reunification, but only after China becomes democratic.

Angered by President Lee Teng-hui's private U.S. visit in mid-1995, Beijing mounted a series of intimidating war games and missile tests in waters near Taiwan until early 1996 to warn the island's people not to drop their reunification pledge.
"That (the war games) shows its unfriendliness and that its threats of force toward us still exist," Chiang said.
Chiang said Taiwan must speed up the renewal of its weapons and raise the quality of its military personnel so that China "dare not start a war hastily."

Under the Defence Ministry's plan, Taiwan will conduct 13 major exercises and training projects, which Chiang described as routine practice, in the July 1996/June 1997 fiscal year to train its soldiers and examine new weapons.

Taiwan has had problems buying advanced weapons from the West under pressure from China, but mobilised its economic clout in 1992 to buy 150 F-16 fighters from Washington and 60 Mirage 2000 fighters from Paris.
Taiwan took delivery of the first F-16s and Mirages in 1996 and "attack helicopters and M60A3 tanks bought from abroad have started to arrive," Chiang said in the report.
Facing China's own rapid military modernisation, Taiwan has been actively strengthening its defences through foreign weapon purchases and the design and production of its own missiles and fighters.
